text: Patient: Okay. I like that. Doctor: Yeah, so we have a plan either Patient: Okay. Doctor: way and I’ll, you know, continue to sort of work through this Patient: Okay. Doctor: . Now, in the meantime, I don’t like you in pain and I think that having a small dose of narcotics like Norco Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm.

text: Patient: I was at 19. Doctor: You were 19 and you’re like at 42 I think Patient: Wow. Doctor: so that’s a hint that uh-oh something’s happening. So, we’ve got 2 options because I’m going to assume that your scans might show something is, maybe 1 or 2 new spots or something. Not drastically worse because you don’t look it. You don’t, that’s not how you are. Certainly, you’re better than the first time I met you. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, you’re in better shape, better control, but we have to get early, you know, we have to get an early jump on this. Let’s say the cancer is back or it’s worse. Well, you had that run of chemo so we’re not going to repeat that but other options would be, we actually have 3 studies to consider Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: but before I get to that let me just tell you what standard of care will be. One might be the vaccine trial which is basically getting your own blood cells to wake up and try to kill the cancer yourself because right now it’s kind of sleeping on the job Mr. S____. You have cancer and your immune cells are like ho-hum, nothing’s happening. It’s still letting the cancer do what it wants so that’s an FDA approved treatment. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: No cure but we have some long-term survival benefits so that’s one option. The other option is a different type of chemo so a cousin of the chemo that you had earlier this year. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: The third one is a pill um and it’s a like a super hormone pill that complements what’s going on with your Lupron injections that oh, you love so much. Those are standard of care like we have no studies going on at Karmanos. I could pick one off the shelf and we’d be good to go Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we do it in this order for everybody. Patient: Okay. Is the castration, the two years, I understand that is standard care. Are there ever any times when that is shortened or – I understand in my case that is likely two years – I accept that that’s what it’s going to be. Doctor: Okay, okay. Family Member: Is that even in case number three, though, the aggressive with the chemo and the super hormone, or is the hormone; I just want to ask In standard care two you said the hormone shot would be for two years. In the third option with the chemo, how long is that going to be last? Doctor: So the way we’re doing it, it’s still two years. Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting.

text: Family Member: Alright. So it is called immunotherapy? Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Um. What’s the difference? There must be different types? Doctor: There’s different types. text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
